definitions.definition: an unreasonable dislike of or preference for a person, group, custom, etc., especially when it is based on their race, religion, sex, etc.
definitions.sensetop: prejudice against somebody/somethingprejudice in favour of somebody/something

examples.text: Their decision was based on ignorance and prejudice.
There was often prejudice against people with disabilities.
She admitted to a prejudice in favour of British universities.
It's hard to break down old prejudices.
He had never encountered such deep prejudice before.
She has not been afraid to challenge popular prejudices.
The tale is told without prejudice or bias.
We must not pander to the irrational prejudices of a small minority.
Anti-Islamic prejudice has increased considerably in recent years.
Anti-gay prejudice was extremely common among people in the army.
He was just talking out of blind prejudice.
I encountered quite serious prejudice when I worked in the construction industry.
I'm afraid all the debate did was confirm my own prejudices.
Irrational prejudice is what drives most racial discrimination in society.
Prejudice towards new immigrants meant that many were unable to find work.
There is still widespread prejudice against people who are HIV-positive.

definitions.definition: without affecting any other legal matter

examples.text: They agreed to pay compensation without prejudice (= without admitting ).

wordOrigin: Middle English (originally as a legal term): from Old French, from Latin praejudicium, from prae ‘in advance’ + judicium ‘judgement’.
